fullProgramDescription: The Jewish Studies major is an interdisciplinary program that explores the history, culture, and literature of the Jewish people from ancient times to the present. The major encompasses a broad range of topics, including biblical studies, rabbinic literature, Jewish history, Israeli culture, and contemporary Jewish issues. Students in the major gain a deep understanding of the Jewish experience and its diverse manifestations across time and geography.
shortProgramDescription: The Jewish Studies major at UCLA provides students with a comprehensive understanding of Jewish history, culture, and literature, preparing them for careers in education, research, and community service.
classHighlights: The Jewish Studies major requires students to complete a series of core courses that introduce them to the major fields of Jewish Studies, including biblical studies, Jewish history, and Jewish literature.
Students in the major can choose from a range of elective courses that explore specific topics in Jewish Studies, such as Israeli culture, Jewish mysticism, and Jewish-American literature.
The major also includes courses in Hebrew language and literature, which provide students with a strong foundation in the language and culture of the Jewish people.
Students can also explore related fields such as history, literature, and cultural studies, allowing them to contextualize their understanding of Jewish Studies within a broader academic framework.
Courses in the major are taught by faculty with expertise in Jewish Studies, ensuring that students receive a rigorous and nuanced education in the field.
learningOutcomes: Demonstrate a broad understanding of Jewish history, culture, and literature
Analyze and interpret Jewish texts and cultural artifacts
Understand the diverse manifestations of Jewish culture across time and geography
Apply knowledge of Jewish Studies to real-world issues and problems
Communicate complex ideas and arguments effectively in writing and speech
additionalInformation: Students must complete the University's writing requirement and American History and Institutions requirements. Students are encouraged to study abroad in Israel or other relevant locations.
